core_claim: In the Finnish town of Sonkajärvi, the annual Wife Carrying World Championship has been held since 1992, where men race through an obstacle course carrying their wives, with the winner receiving the wife's weight in beer.

supporting_details.date: Annual event since 1992, held in July

source_citation: Official Wife Carrying Competition website (eukonkanto.fi); The Finnish Tourist Board
why_strange: A competitive sport centered entirely around men carrying women through obstacles for beer

core_claim: During La Tomatina festival in Buñol, Spain, approximately 150,000 tomatoes (over 40 tons) are thrown in the streets during a massive food fight that lasts exactly one hour, with strict rules including crushing tomatoes before throwing them.

supporting_details.date: Last Wednesday of August annually since 1945
supporting_details.origin: Began from a spontaneous fight during a parade in 1945

source_citation: Official Tourism Board of Spain; Buñol Town Council; UNESCO Cultural Heritage documentation
why_strange: An entire town transforms into a regulated tomato battlefield where 40 tons of food are deliberately wasted in 60 minutes

core_claim: In the Tibetan Sky Burial (Jhator), human corpses are cut into pieces and placed on mountaintops to be consumed by vultures, as the ground is too hard for burial and wood too scarce for cremation.

supporting_details.date: Practice dates back at least 12,000 years
supporting_details.location: Tibet, parts of Mongolia, Qinghai, and Sichuan
supporting_details.process: Body is dismembered by a rogyapa (body-breaker), bones are ground with tsampa (barley flour), then fed to vultures
supporting_details.spiritual_basis: Represents the deceased's final act of generosity (dana) by feeding wildlife

source_citation: Journal of the Royal Anthropological Institute; Tibet Museum documentation; 'Sky Burial: An Eyewitness Account' by Blake Kerr, M.D.
why_strange: A funeral practice where the body is deliberately fed to wild birds rather than preserved or ceremonially burned

core_claim: The Indonesian Toraja people keep their deceased relatives at home for years or even decades after death, treating them as 'sick' rather than dead, dressing, feeding, and talking to them daily until funds are gathered for an elaborate funeral.

supporting_details.funeral_cost: Equivalent to tens of thousands of USD
supporting_details.ceremony: Ma'nene ritual includes periodically removing, cleaning and redressing corpses

source_citation: National Geographic documentary 'Living with the Dead'; Journal of Southeast Asian Studies; Indonesian Ministry of Tourism documentation
why_strange: Dead family members are treated as living household members for years before their actual funeral

core_claim: In the Torajan culture of Indonesia, families exhume the bodies of deceased relatives every few years to clean, groom, and dress them in fresh clothes during the Ma'nene ritual.

supporting_details.activities: Exhuming corpses, changing clothes, cleaning remains, parading bodies

source_citation: National Geographic, 'The Indonesian Village Where the Dead Live With Their Families', 2016; BBC Travel, 'The Indonesian ritual that celebrates the dead', 2017
why_strange: Most cultures avoid contact with corpses, but here they are lovingly maintained and celebrated

core_claim: Every spring in El Colacho, Spain, men dressed as devils leap over rows of infants lying on mattresses as part of a 400-year-old baby-cleansing ritual.

supporting_details.date: Annually during the festival of Corpus Christi in late May or June
supporting_details.location: Castrillo de Murcia, near Burgos, Spain
supporting_details.participants: Local men dressed as 'El Colacho' (the devil), infants born in the previous year
supporting_details.purpose: To cleanse babies of original sin and protect them from evil spirits

source_citation: The Guardian, 'Spanish baby-jumping festival El Colacho marks 400 years', 2015; Smithsonian Magazine, 'Spain’s Baby-Jumping Festival Is as Strange as It Sounds', 2012
why_strange: It involves literally jumping over live babies to ward off evil

core_claim: In Denmark, people who are unmarried at age 25 are traditionally pelted with cinnamon by friends and family in a public celebration.

supporting_details.date: Modern-day tradition, especially observed on birthdays
supporting_details.participants: Unmarried individuals turning 25 (called 'kanelsnegle'), friends and family
supporting_details.materials_used: Large quantities of ground cinnamon, sometimes water for it to stick
supporting_details.custom_variation: At age 30, pepper is used instead

source_citation: The Local Denmark, 'Why Danes pelt their single 25-year-old friends with cinnamon', 2018; BBC Travel, 'The Danish tradition that singles dread', 2019
why_strange: It's a cheerful public shaming involving spices for being single
